Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii

David,
Thanks for the help--the binary windows install works. I spent a couple of hours on a flight getting it to go. It seems as if there is a small bug in that cantera expects Python to be at C:\Python23\python no matter what path you use. I tried to have it on D:, but it would never work. But, I just finally put Python on C: and it now works fine. Now, I'll be doing tutorials on the return flight! Thanks again. By the way, we met at the ECS conference in San Antonio after I gave a talk showing the Chemkin mechanism for preferential oxidation of CO.
Thanks,
Ron Besser

David Goodwin <dgoodwin@...> wrote:
Ron,

In that case the best thing to do is just use the binary installer for 
Windows. Download and run Cantera154.msi. This will install 
everything you need to use Cantera from Python or Matlab.
Then you don't even have to have cygwin, or bother with running 
'configure' etc.

But to answer your question - it seems you have an incomplete 
installation of cygwin, or some path problem, if even 'ls' doesn't 
work.

Dave

On Jun 19, 2004, at 6:03 AM, Ron Besser wrote:

> Sorry for this question. I'm not a UNIX programmer, just a chemical 
> researcher. In trying to do the installation of Cantera for Windows 
> XP, I'm trying to run configure from the cygwin command line and I get 
> "configure: command not found." I know I have reached the directory 
> where the cantera install files (including the configure files) are. 
> Also, the basic unix command ls doesn't work. I'm know I'm doing 
> something very basic incorrectly. Help!
>  
> Thanks,
> Ron Besser
